ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I have learned a great deal about original historical writing and research.
How to start writing a 50 page essay
How to do a long-term project

This has been a very helpful and rewarding mentorship experience. I have learned a lot about how to do archival research and have been pushed to explore new ways of interrogating and interpreting my sources.

I was able to develop my research skills in sorting through books and archives at the Yale Library, the University of Kentucky library, and the East Tennessee State University library. I also learned more about how anti-Communist movements such as McCarthyism both successfully and unsuccessfully undermined postwar social justice movements.
I learned how to develop a research plan for a year-long thesis.
How to prepare for writing a research essay. How to locate primary sources.

This is my first time completing a long-form research essay by sifting through primary sources, communicating closely with my librarian, and completing milestone tasks throughout the course of the fall semester.
I learned more about John Henry Newman and the history research process.

I learned how to gather a variety of primary and secondary sources in preparation for an extensive research project. I also developed my research skills, particularly reading through a large amount of content and gleaning the important information in a more time efficient manner.

I gained a much deeper understanding of primary source research, including how to dig deep into texts and think critically about authorship and audience. I learned how to build a long-term research project from the ground up, beginning with a set of anchoring primary and secondary sources. I also learned how to peer review other students' work and provide thoughtful and concise feedback.

I was able to take on the challenge of a long-form essay while doing so with the freedom of choosing my own topic. Throughout this semester, I was able to conduct all sorts of research (interviews, archival documents, audio files, etc.) and put everything together to make a new historical argument.
researching for a thesis, taking notes on sources, formulating a good topic
The senior essay has been a rocky process but overall I've gotten some good work done on my thesis during the fall semester. I've started important research and I've begun organizing my work.
I've gotten much better at research and structuring a persuasive and unique argument

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It would be very helpful for more information to be sent out ahead of time, such as in the spring semester of junior year.  Not having an advisor at the beginning of the year set me behind quite a bit and has made it difficult to catch up.
I would have been helped more if the course had an actual class that met rather than only relying on the advisor
A worthwhile experience
Well organizedwas very easy to keep track of what I needed to do.

Strengths: lots of checkpoints along the way, great advisor, very flexible

Weaknesses: none!
Very poorly organized
This course could be more structured.
The deadlines should be a little more spread out for the senior essay, but overall the distribution of work over the semester is good

Strengths: deadlines help you keep yourself on track. 
Weaknesses: I think the 10 page draft requirement should be changed to an outline.
A good way to learn how to research history.

I thought the milestone due dates prevented me from accomplishing more in my thesis this semester. I felt like the bulk of the assignments served the purpose of reminding us to think about our thesis research, but most did not actually move me closer towards completing my research and thesis. Instead, I spent time completing what felt like busy-work that I would have otherwise spent on research.

That said, I thought the initial milestones for meeting with a librarian and creating a bibliography were very helpful. I also enjoyed meeting with my thesis adviser.

The Senior Essay is a great way to get history students to push themselves in their senior year. It has forced me to rethink how I write and convey my narrative of the past to my reader. I can definitely see how by the end of next semester, I will be an entirely different student and thinker than when I started the process. I think one criticism would be that the opening orientation session was not so helpful. Some of the speakers highlighted how long and intimidating the project is, how important it will be in the scheme of our lives. Students are already very anxious about their theses  I think the focus of that opening session should be building students' passion for history and love for the work, rather than encouraging us to worry about the thesis from the get go.
I really appreciated the weekly meetings with my advisor as well as the freedom to go into a topic of my choice. I can not think of any way the current structure could be improved.

I think the history department could do so much more to support its students throughout the senior essay process. I did not hear from the history department during the fall semester unless it was them reminding us of an impending deadline. But there is no organized support or guidance to help students approach or complete all the different requirements of the project. And for those of us who have little experience with these types of assignments, the history department should be doing much more than it currently is to help.
Strengths - got me doing deep research much earlier than I would have given the deadlines; weaknesses - I wish there were more examples available of senior essays and more overall guidance

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!  Get a good advisor, find a topic you're interested in, and this can be a very rewarding process.
If you are in the major then yes.
yes
Yes!! I think the year-long history thesis has made my writing process much easier with a lot of the goal posts along the way.
Lol unless u dont want to graduate yes
n/a
I mean you have to take it if you're a history major so i feel neutral
It is a requirement.
yes
It is a requirement for the full-term history senior essay. That said, it is very helpful to have an entire credit devoted towards independent research.
Yes, of course. The history thesis is an amazing opportunity to dig deep with a professor who makes history exciting and enjoyable!
Certainly. The two-semester format is a great opportunity to produce a substantive piece of historical research and a great deal of fun as well.

No. The senior essay is a great opportunity to finish off your senior year by completing original work. However, the history department has thus far been absolutely useless in helping students through this process. Therefore, I would advise to anyone considering a history thesis that they will likely have to go it alone because the department is not helpful.
yes, the process of research has been really great so far
